arabicText: ١١٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَا مَالَ أَعْوَدُ مِنَ الْعَقْلِ، وَلَا وَحْدَةَ أَوْحَشُ مِنَ الْعُجْب، وَلَا عَقْلَ كَالتَّدْبِيرِ، وَلَا كَرَمَ كَالتَّقْوَى، وَلَا قَرين كَحُسنِ الخُلْقِ، وَلَا مِيرَاثَ كَالْأَدَبِ، وَلَا قَائِدَ كَالتَّوْفِيقِ، وَلَا تِجَارَةَ كَالْعَمَلِ الصَّالِحِ، وَلَا رِبْحَ كَالثَّوَابِ، وَلَا وَرَعَ كالْوُقُوفِ عِنْدَ الشُّبْهَةِ، وَلَا زُهْدَ كَالزُّهْدِ فِي الْحَرَامِ، وَلَا عِلْمَ كَالتَّفَكُّرِ، وَلَا عِبَادَةَ كَأَدَاءِ الْفَرائِضِ، وَلَا إِيمَانَ كَالْحَيَاءِ وَالصَّبْرِ، وَلَا حَسَبَ كَالتَّوَاضُعِ، وَلَا شَرَفَ كَالْعِلْمِ، وَلَا مُظَاهَرَةَ أَوْثَقُ مِن مُشَاوَرَةٍ.

chapter: Human fragility and mortality's inevitability
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 115. It was said to Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him: How are you, O Amīr al-mu’minīn? and he replied: How can he be whom life is driving towards death, whose state of healthiness can change into sickness any moment and who is to be caught (by death) from his place of safety.
arabicText: ١١٥. وَقِيلَ لَهُ (عليه ‏السلام): كَيْفَ نَجِدُكَ يَا أَمِيرَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ فَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): كَيْفَ يَكُونُ حَالُ مَنْ يَفْنَى بِبَقَائِهِ وَيَسْقَمُ بِصِحَّتِهِ وَيُؤْتَى مِنْ مَأْمَنِهِ.

chapter: Divine patience and human deception
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 116. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: There are many people who are given time (by Allāh) through good treatment towards them, and many who are deceived because their sinful activities are veiled (by Allāh), and many who are enamoured by good talk about themselves. And Allāh does not try anyone as seriously as He tries him whom He allows time (to remain sinful).
arabicText: ١١٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): كَمْ مِنْ مُسْتَدْرَجٍ بِالْإِحْسَانِ إِلَيْهِ وَمَغْرُورٍ بِالسَّتْرِ عَلَيْهِ وَمَفْتُونٍ بِحُسْنِ الْقَوْلِ فِيهِ وَمَا ابْتَلَى اللَّهُ أَحَداً بِمِثْلِ الْإِمْلَاءِ لَهُ.

chapter: Missing opportunities causes grief
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 118. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: To miss an opportunity brings about grief.
arabicText: ١١٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِضَاعَةُ الْفُرْصَةِ غُصَّةٌ.

chapter: World likened to a deceptive serpent
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 119. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The example of the world is like a serpent. It is soft to the touch but its inside is full of venom. An ignorant person who has fallen into deceit is attracted towards it but a wise and intelligent man keeps on his guard against it.
arabicText: ١١٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَثَلُ الدُّنْيَا كَمَثَلِ الْحَيَّةِ لَيِّنٌ مَسُّهَا وَالسَّمُّ النَّاقِعُ فِى جَوْفِهَا يَهْوِى إِلَيْهَا الْغِرُّ الْجَاهِلُ وَيَحْذَرُهَا ذُو اللُّبِّ الْعَاقِلُ.

chapter: Contrasting transient pleasures with lasting rewards
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 121. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: What a difference there is between two kinds of actions: an act whose pleasure passes away but its (ill) consequence remains, and. the act whose hardship passes away but its reward stays.
arabicText: ١٢١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): شَتَّانَ مَا بَيْنَ عَمَلَيْنِ: عَمَلٍ تَذْهَبُ لَذَّتُهُ وَتَبْقَى تَبِعَتُهُ، وَعَمَلٍ تَذْهَبُ مَؤُونَتُهُ وَيَبْقَى أَجْرُهُ.

chapter: The folly of ignoring mortality and divine warnings
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 122. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, was accompanying a funeral when he heard someone laugh. Then he said : Is it that death has been ordained only for others? Is it that right is obligatory only on others? Is it that those whom we see departing on their journey of death will come back to us? We lay them down in their graves and then enjoy their estate (as if we will live for good after them). We have ignored every preacher, man or woman, and have exposed ourselves to every catastrophe.
arabicText: ١٢٢. وَتَبِعَ جِنَازَةً فَسَمِعَ رَجُلًا يَضْحَكُ فَقَالَ كَأَنَّ الْمَوْتَ فِيهَا عَلَى غَيْرِنَا كُتِبَ وَكَأَنَّ الْحَقَّ فِيهَا عَلَى غَيْرِنَا وَجَبَ وَكَأَنَّ الَّذِى نَرَى مِنَ الْأَمْوَاتِ سَفْرٌ عَمَّا قَلِيلٍ إِلَيْنَا رَاجِعُونَ. نُبَوِّئُهُمْ أَجْدَاثَهُمْ وَنَأْكُلُ تُرَاثَهُمْ كَأَنَّا مُخَلَّدُونَ بَعْدَهُمْ ثُمَّ قَدْ نَسِينَا كُلَّ وَاعِظٍ وَوَاعِظَةٍ وَرُمِينَا بِكُلِّ فَادِحٍ وَجَائِحَةٍ.

chapter: Gender differences in jealousy as heresy versus belief
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 124. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The jealousy of a woman (with co-wives) is heresy, while the jealousy of a man is a part of belief.
arabicText: ١٢٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): غَيْرَةُ الْمَرْأَةِ كُفْرٌ وَغَيْرَةُ الرَّجُلِ إِيمَانٌ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's reflections on human folly and divine wisdom
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 126. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: I wonder at the miser who is speeding towards the very destitution from which he wants to run away and misses the very ease of life which he covets. Consequently, he passes his life in this world like the destitute, but will have to render an account in the next world like the rich.
arabicText: ١٢٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): عَجِبْتُ لِلْبَخِيلِ يَسْتَعْجِلُ الْفَقْرَ الَّذِى مِنْهُ هَرَبَ وَيَفُوتُهُ الْغِنَى الَّذِى إِيَّاهُ طَلَبَ فَيَعِيشُ فِى الدُّنْيَا عَيْشَ الْفُقَرَاءِ وَيُحَاسَبُ فِى الْآخِرَةِ حِسَابَ الْأَغْنِيَاءِ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's reflections on human folly and divine wisdom
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: I wonder at the proud man who was just a drop of semen the other day and will turn into a corpse tomorrow. I wonder at the man who doubts Allāh although he sees His creations. I wonder at him who has forgotten death although he sees people dying. I wonder at him who denies the second life although he has seen the first life. I wonder at him who inhabits this transient abode but ignores the everlasting abode.
arabicText: وَعَجِبْتُ لِلْمُتَكَبِّرِ الَّذِى كَانَ بِالْأَمْسِ نُطْفَةً وَيَكُونُ غَداً جِيفَةً وَعَجِبْتُ لِمَنْ شَكَّ فِى اللَّهِ وَهُوَ يَرَى خَلْقَ اللَّهِ وَعَجِبْتُ لِمَنْ نَسِيَ الْمَوْتَ وَهُوَ يَرَى الْمَوْتَى وَعَجِبْتُ لِمَنْ أَنْكَرَ النَّشْأَةَ الْأُخْرَى وَهُوَ يَرَى النَّشْأَةَ الْأُولَى وَعَجِبْتُ لِعَامِرٍ دَارَ الْفَنَاءِ وَتَارِكٍ دَارَ الْبَقَاءِ.

chapter: Seasonal health precautions against cold extremes
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 128. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Guard against cold in its (seasonal) beginning and welcome it towards its end because it effects bodies in the same way as it effects plants. In the beginning, it destroys them but in the end it gives them fresh leaves. [1]
arabicText: ١٢٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): تَوَقَّوُا الْبَرْدَ فِى أَوَّلِهِ وَتَلَقَّوْهُ فِى آخِرِهِ فَإِنَّهُ يَفْعَلُ فِى الْأَبْدَانِ كَفِعْلِهِ فِى الْأَشْجَارِ أَوَّلُهُ يُحْرِقُ وَآخِرُهُ يُورِقُ.

chapter: Divine greatness diminishes worldly perceptions
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 129. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Greatness of the Creator appreciated by you would belittle the creatures in your view.
arabicText: ١٢٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): عِظَمُ الْخَالِقِ عِنْدَكَ يُصَغِّرُ الْمَخْلُوقَ فِى عَيْنِكَ.

chapter: Critique of worldliness and its transient nature
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 131. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, heard a man abusing the world and said: O you who abuse the world, O you who have been deceived by its deceit and cheated by its wrongs. Do you covet the world and then abuse it? Do you accuse it or it should accuse you? When did it bewilder you or deceive you whether by the decay and fall of your forefathers, or by the sleeping places of your mothers under the ground? How much you looked after them in their illness and nursed them during sickness, desiring them to be cured and consulting physicians for them in the morning when your medicine did not avail them and your wailing for them did not benefit them. Your mourning over them did not prove useful to them and you could not achieve your aims. You could not ward off (death) from them with all your power. In fact, through the dying man the world presented an illustration for you and showed you by the example of his falling down how you would (also) fall.
arabicText: ١٣١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): وَقَدْ سَمِعَ رَجُلًا يَذُمُّ الدُّنْيَا أَيُّهَا الذَّامُّ لِلدُّنْيَا الْمُغْتَرُّ بِغُرُورِهَا الْمَخْدُوعُ بِأَبَاطِيلِهَا أَ تَغْتَرُّ بِالدُّنْيَا ثُمَّ تَذُمُّهَا أَنْتَ الْمُتَجَرِّمُ عَلَيْهَا أَمْ هِيَ الْمُتَجَرِّمَةُ عَلَيْكَ مَتَى اسْتَهْوَتْكَ أَمْ مَتَى غَرَّتْكَ أَ بِمَصَارِعِ آبَائِكَ مِنَ الْبِلَى أَمْ بِمَضَاجِعِ أُمَّهَاتِكَ تَحْتَ الثَّرَى كَمْ عَلَّلْتَ بِكَفَّيْكَ وَكَمْ مَرَّضْتَ بِيَدَيْكَ تَبْتَغِى لَهُمُ الشِّفَاءَ وَتَسْتَوْصِفُ لَهُمُ الْأَطِبَّاءَ غَدَاةَ لَا يُغْنِى عَنْهُمْ دَوَاؤُكَ وَلَا يُجْدِى عَلَيْهِمْ بُكَاؤُكَ لَمْ يَنْفَعْ أَحَدَهُمْ إِشْفَاقُكَ وَلَمْ تُسْعَفْ فِيهِ بِطَلِبَتِكَ وَلَمْ تَدْفَعْ عَنْهُ بِقُوَّتِكَ وَقَدْ مَثَّلَتْ لَكَ بِهِ الدُّنْيَا نَفْسَكَ وَبِمَصْرَعِهِ مَصْرَعَكَ.

chapter: Critique of worldliness and its transient nature
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Certainly, this world is a house of truth for him who appreciates it; a place of safety for him who understands it; a house of riches for him who collects provision from it (for the next world); and a house of instructions for him who draws instruction from it. It is the place of worship for the lovers of Allāh; the place of praying for the angels of Allāh; the place where the revelation of Allāh descends; and the marketing place for those devoted to Allāh. Herein they earned mercy and herein they acquired Paradise by way of profit.
arabicText: إِنَّ الدُّنْيَا دَارُ صِدْقٍ لِمَنْ صَدَقَهَا وَدَارُ عَافِيَةٍ لِمَنْ فَهِمَ عَنْهَا وَدَارُ غِنًى لِمَنْ تَزَوَّدَ مِنْهَا وَدَارُ مَوْعِظَةٍ لِمَنِ اتَّعَظَ بِهَا مَسْجِدُ أَحِبَّاءِ اللَّهِ وَمُصَلَّى مَلَائِكَةِ اللَّهِ وَمَهْبِطُ وَحْيِ اللَّهِ وَمَتْجَرُ أَوْلِيَاءِ اللَّهِ اكْتَسَبُوا فِيهَا الرَّحْمَةَ وَرَبِحُوا فِيهَا الْجَنَّةَ.

chapter: Critique of worldliness and its transient nature
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Therefore, who can abuse it when it has announced its departure and called out that it would leave! It had given news of its own destruction and the death of its people. By its hardship it set an example of their hardships. By its pleasures it created eagerness for the pleasures (of the next world). It brings ease in the evening and grief in the morning by way of persuasion, dissuasion, alarm and warning. People abuse it on the morning of their repentance but there are others who will praise it on the Day of Judgement. The world recalled to them the next life and they bore it in mind. It related to them (things of the next life) and they acknowledged them. It preached to them and they took lesson therefrom. [1]
arabicText: فَمَنْ ذَا يَذُمُّهَا وَقَدْ آذَنَتْ بِبَيْنِهَا وَنَادَتْ بِفِرَاقِهَا وَنَعَتْ نَفْسَهَا وَأَهْلَهَا فَمَثَّلَتْ لَهُمْ بِبَلَائِهَا الْبَلَاءَ وَشَوَّقَتْهُمْ بِسُرُورِهَا إِلَى السُّرُورِ رَاحَتْ بِعَافِيَةٍ وَابْتَكَرَتْ بِفَجِيعَةٍ تَرْغِيباً وَتَرْهِيباً وَتَخْوِيفاً وَتَحْذِيراً فَذَمَّهَا رِجَالٌ غَدَاةَ النَّدَامَةِ وَحَمِدَهَا آخَرُونَ يَوْمَ الْقِيَامَةِ ذَكَّرَتْهُمُ الدُّنْيَا فَتَذَكَّرُوا وَحَدَّثَتْهُمْ فَصَدَّقُوا وَوَعَظَتْهُمْ فَاتَّعَظُوا.

chapter: Life's transience and worldly impermanence
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 132. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: There is an angel of Allāh who calls out every day, “Beget children for death, collect wealth for destruction, and raise construction for ruin.”
arabicText: ١٣٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِنَّ لِلَّهِ مَلَكاً يُنَادِى فِى كُلِّ يَوْمٍ لِدُوا لِلْمَوْتِ وَاجْمَعُوا لِلْفَنَاءِ وَابْنُوا لِلْخَرَابِ.

chapter: True friendship in adversity, absence, and death
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 134. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: A friend is not a friend unless he affords protection to his comrade on three occasions: in his adversity, in his absence and at his death.
arabicText: ١٣٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَا يَكُونُ الصَّدِيقُ صَدِيقاً حَتَّى يَحْفَظَ أَخَاهُ فِى ثَلَاثٍ فِى نَكْبَتِهِ وَغَيْبَتِهِ وَوَفَاتِهِ.

chapter: Prayer as divine proximity and fasting as bodily devotion
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 136. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: For the God-fearing prayers is a means of seeking nearness to Allāh; and for the weak the ḥajj (pilgrimage to Mecca) is as good as jihād (fighting in the way of Allāh). For every thing there is a levy; and the levy of the body is fasting. The jihād of a woman is to afford pleasant company to her husband.
arabicText: ١٣٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الصَّلَاةُ قُرْبَانُ كُلِّ تَقِيٍّ وَالْحَجُّ جِهَادُ كُلِّ ضَعِيفٍ وَلِكُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ زَكَاةٌ وَ زَكَاةُ الْبَدَنِ الصِّيَامُ وَجِهَادُ الْمَرْأَةِ حُسْنُ التَّبَعُّلِ.

chapter: Seeking livelihood through almsgiving
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 137. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Seek livelihood by giving alms.
arabicText: ١٣٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): اسْتَنْزِلُوا الرِّزْقَ بِالصَّدَقَةِ.

chapter: Assistance permitted based on necessity
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 139. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Assistance is allowed according to need.
arabicText: ١٣٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): تَنْزِلُ الْمَعُونَةُ عَلَى قَدْرِ الْمَئُونَةِ.

chapter: Moderation prevents destitution
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 140. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who is moderate does not become destitute.
arabicText: ١٤٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَا عَالَ مَنِ اقْتَصَدَ.

chapter: Small families ensure ease
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 141. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: A small family is one of the ways of (securing) ease.
arabicText: ١٤١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): قِلَّةُ الْعِيَالِ أَحَدُ الْيَسَارَيْنِ.

chapter: Grief as half of old age
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 143. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Grief is half of old age.
arabicText: ١٤٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الْهَمُّ نِصْفُ الْهَرَم.

chapter: Endurance proportional to affliction
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 144. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Endurance comes according to the affliction. He who beats his hand on the thigh in his affliction ruins all his good actions.
arabicText: ١٤٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): يَنْزِلُ الصَّبْرُ عَلَى قَدْرِ الْمُصِيبَةِ، وَمَنْ ضَرَبَ يَدَهُ عَلَى فَخِذِهِ عِنْدَ مُصِيبَتِهِ حَبِطَ أجْرُهُ.

chapter: Safeguarding belief through charity and prayer
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 146. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Protect your belief by charity; guard your wealth by paying Allāh’s share; and ward off the waves of calamity by praying.
arabicText: ١٤٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): سُوسُواإِيمَانَكُمْ بِالصَّدَقَةِ، وَحَصِّنُوا أَمْوَالَكُمْ بِالزَّكَاةِ، وَادْفَعُوا أَمْواجَ الْبَلاَءِ بِالدُّعَاءِ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 147. Amīr al-mu’minīn’s Conversation with Kumayl Ibn Ziyād an-Nakha‘ī [1]
arabicText: ١٤٧. وَمِنْ كَلَامٍ لَهُ (عليه السلام) لِكُمَيْلِ بْنِ زِيَادٍ النَّخَعِيِّ

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Kumayl ibn Ziyād has related: Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, caught hold of my hand and took me to the graveyard. When he had passed through the graveyard and left the city behind, he breathed a deep sigh and said:
arabicText: قَالَ كُمَيْلُ بْنُ زِيَادٍ: أَخَذَ بِيَدِي أَمِيرُ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ عَلِيُّ بْنُ أَبِي طَالِبٍ (عليه السلام)، فَأَخْرَجَنِي إِلَى الْجَبَّانِ فَلَمَّا أَصْحَرَ تَنَفَّسَ الصُّعَدَاءَ ثُمَّ قَالَ:

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: O Kumayl, these hearts are containers. The best of them is that which preserves (its contents). So, preserve what I say to you:
arabicText: يَا كُمَيْل بْن زِيَادٍ، إِنَّ هذهِ الْقُلُوبَ أَوْعِيَةٌ فَخَيْرُهَا أَوْعَاهَا فَاحْفَظْ عَنِّي مَا أَقُولُ لَكَ:

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: People are of three types: One is the scholar and divine; then the seeker of knowledge who is also on the way to deliverance. Then (lastly) the common rot who run after every caller and bend in the direction of every wind. They seek no light from the effulgence of knowledge and do not take protection of any reliable support.
arabicText: النَّاسُ ثَلاَثَةٌ: فَعَالِمٌ رَبَّانِيٌّ وَمُتَعَلِّمٌ عَلَى سَبِيلِ نَجَاةٍ، وَهَمَجٌ رَعَاعٌ أَتْبَاعُ كُلِّ نَاعِقٍ يَمِيلُونَ مَعَ كُلِّ رِيحٍ، لَمْ يَسْتَضِيئُوا بِنُورِ الْعِلْمِ، وَلَمْ يَلْجَؤُوا إِلَى رُكْنٍ وَثِيقٍ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: O Kumayl, knowledge is better than wealth. Knowledge guards you, while you have to guard the wealth. Wealth decreases by spending, while knowledge multiplies by spending, and the results of wealth die as wealth decays.
arabicText: يَا كُمَيْلُ، الْعِلْمُ خَيْرٌ مِنَ الْمَالِ: الْعِلْمُ يَحْرُسُكَ وَأَنْتَ تَحْرُسُ المَالَ، وَالْمَالُ تَنْقُصُهُ النَّفَقَةُ، وَالْعِلْمُ يَزْكُوعَلَى الْإِنْفَاقِ، وَصَنِيعُ الْمَالِ يَزُولُ بِزَوَالِهِ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: O Kumayl, knowledge is belief which is acted upon. With it man acquires obedience during his life and a good name after his death. Knowledge is the ruler while wealth is ruled upon.
arabicText: يَا كُمَيْلَ بْنَ زِيَادٍ مَعْرِفَةُ الْعِلْمِ دِينٌ يُدَانُ بِهِ بِهِ يَكْسِبُ الْإِنْسَانُ الطَّاعَةَ فِى حَيَاتِهِ وَجَمِيلَ الْأُحْدُوثَةِ بَعْدَ وَفَاتِهِ وَ الْعِلْمُ حَاكِمٌ وَالْمَالُ مَحْكُومٌ عَلَيْهِ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: O Kumayl, those who amass wealth are dead even though they may be living while those endowed with knowledge will remain as long as the world lives. Their bodies are not available but their figures exist in the hearts. Look, here is a heap of knowledge (and Amīr al-mu’minīn pointed to his bosom). I wish I could get someone to bear it. Yes, I did find (such a one); but either he was one who could not be relied upon. He would exploit the religion for worldly gains, and by virtue of Allāh’s favours on him he would domineer over the people and through Allāh’s pleas he would lord over His devotees. Or he was one who was obedient to the hearers of truth but there was no intelligence in his bosom. At the first appearance of doubt he would entertain misgivings in his heart.
arabicText: يَا كُمَيْلُ هَلَكَ خُزَّانُ الْأَمْوَالِ وَهُمْ أَحْيَاءٌ وَ الْعُلَمَاءُ بَاقُونَ مَا بَقِيَ الدَّهْرُ أَعْيَانُهُمْ مَفْقُودَةٌ وَأَمْثَالُهُمْ فِى الْقُلُوبِ مَوْجُودَةٌ هَا إِنَّ هَاهُنَا لَعِلْماً جَمّاً وَأَشَارَ بِيَدِهِ إِلَى صَدْرِهِ لَوْ أَصَبْتُ لَهُ حَمَلَةً بَلَى أَصَبْتُ لَقِناً غَيْرَ مَأْمُونٍ عَلَيْهِ مُسْتَعْمِلًا آلَةَ الدِّينِ لِلدُّنْيَا وَمُسْتَظْهِراً بِنِعَمِ اللَّهِ عَلَى عِبَادِهِ وَبِحُجَجِهِ عَلَى أَوْلِيَائِهِ أَوْ مُنْقَاداً لِحَمَلَةِ الْحَقِّ لَا بَصِيرَةَ لَهُ فِى أَحْنَائِهِ يَنْقَدِحُ الشَّكُّ فِى قَلْبِهِ لِأَوَّلِ عَارِضٍ مِنْ شُبْهَةٍ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: So, neither this nor that was good enough. Either the man is eager for pleasures, easily led away by passions, or is covetous for collecting and hoarding wealth. Neither of them has any regard for religion in any matter. The nearest example of these is the loose cattle. This is the way that knowledge dies away with the death of its bearers.
arabicText: أَلَا لَا ذَا وَلَا ذَاكَ أَوْ مَنْهُوماً بِاللَّذَّةِ سَلِسَ الْقِيَادِ لِلشَّهْوَةِ أَوْ مُغْرَماً بِالْجَمْعِ وَالِادِّخَارِ لَيْسَا مِنْ رُعَاةِ الدِّينِ فِى شَيْ‏ءٍ أَقْرَبُ شَيْ‏ءٍ شَبَهاً بِهِمَا الْأَنْعَامُ السَّائِمَةُ كَذَلِكَ يَمُوتُ الْعِلْمُ بِمَوْتِ حَامِلِيهِ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: O My Allāh! Yes; but the earth is never devoid of those who maintain Allāh’s plea either openly and reputedly or, being afraid, as hidden in order that Allāh’s pleas and proofs should not be rebutted. How many are they and where are they? By Allāh, they are few in number, but they are great in esteem before Allāh. Through them Allāh guards His pleas and proofs till they entrust them to others like themselves and sow the seeds thereof in the hearts of those who are similar to them.
arabicText: اللَّهُمَّ بَلَى! لَا تَخْلُو الْأَرْضُ مِنْ قَائِمٍ لله بِحُجَّةٍ، إِمَّا ظَاهِراً مَشْهُوراً، وَإِمَّا خَائِفاً مَغْمُوراً لِئَلاَّ تَبْطُلَ حُجَجُ اللهِ وَبَيِّنَاتُهُ. وَكَمْ ذَا وَأَيْنَ أُولئِكَ؟ أُولئِكَ ـ وَاللَّهِ ـ الْأَقَلُّونَ عَدَداً، وَالْأَعْظَمُونَ عِنْدَ اللَّهِ قَدْراً، يَحْفَظُ اللهُ بِهِمْ حُجَجَهُ وَبَيِّنَاتِهِ، حَتَّى يُودِعُوهَا نُظَرَاءَهُمْ، وَيَزْرَعُوهَا فِي قُلُوبِ أَشْبَاهِهِمْ،

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Knowledge has led them to real understanding and so they have associated themselves with the spirit of conviction. They take easy what the easygoing regard as hard. They endear what the ignorant take as strange. They live in this world with their bodies here but their spirits resting in the high above. They are the vicegerents of Allah on His earth and callers to His religion.
arabicText: هَجَمَ بِهِمُ الْعِلْمُ عَلَى حَقِيقَةِ الْبَصِيرَةِ، وَبَاشَرُوا رُوحَ الْيَقِينِ، وَاسْتَلاَنُوامَا اسْتَوْعَرَهُ الْمُتْرَفُونَ وَأَنِسُوا بِمَا اسْتَوْحَشَ مِنْهُ الْجَاهِلُونَ، وَصَحِبُوا الدُّنْيَا بِأَبْدَانٍ أَرْوَاحُهَا مُعَلَّقَةٌ بِالْـمَحَلِّ الْأَعْلَى، أُولئِكَ خُلَفَاءُ اللهِ فِي أَرْضِهِ، وَالدُّعَاةُ إِلَى دِينِهِ،

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's wisdom on knowledge and virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Oh, oh, how I yearn to see them! Go away now, O Kumayl, wherever you wish!
arabicText: آهِ آهِ شَوْقاً إِلَى رُؤْيَتِهِمْ! انْصَرِفْ (يَا كُمَيْلُ) إِذَا شِئْتَ.

chapter: Self-awareness as the foundation of success
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 149. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who does not know his own worth is ruined.
arabicText: ١٤٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): هَلَكَ امْرُؤُ لَمْ يَعْرِفْ قَدْرَهُ.

chapter: Human mortality and inevitable fate
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 151. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Every human being has to meet the end, sweet or bitter.
arabicText: ١٥١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لِكُلِّ امْرِئٍ عَاقِبَةٌ حُلْوَةٌ أَوْ مُرَّةٌ.

chapter: The transient nature of human existence
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 152. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Every comer has to return and after returning it is as though he never existed.
arabicText: ١٥٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لِكُلِّ مُقْبِلٍ إِدْبَارٌ، وَمَا أَدْبَرَ كَأَنْ لَمْ يَكُنْ.

chapter: Endurance ensures eventual success
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 153. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The endurer does not miss success although it may take a long time.
arabicText: ١٥٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَا يَعْدَمُ الصَّبُورُ الظَّفَرَ وَإِنْ طَالَ بِهِ الزَّمَانُ.

chapter: Adhering to contracts with steadfast fulfillment
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 155. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Adhere to contracts and entrust their fulfilment to steadfast persons.
arabicText: ١٥٥. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): اعْتَصِمُوا بِالذِّمَمِ فِي أَوْتَادِهَا.

chapter: Obligation of obedience to the undeniable authority
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 156. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: On you lies (the obligation of) obedience to the person about whom you cannot plead the excuse of ignorance. [1]
arabicText: ١٥٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): عَلَيْكُمْ بِطَاعَةِ مَنْ لَا تُعْذَرُونَ بِجَهَالَتِهِ.

chapter: Encouraging virtue through kindness and benevolence
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 158. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Admonish your brother (comrade) by good behaviour towards him, and ward off his evil by favouring him. [1]
arabicText: ١٥٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): عَاتِبْ أَخَاكَ بِالْإِحْسَانِ إِلَيْهِ، وَارْدُدْ شَرَّهُ بِالْإِنْعَامِ عَلَيْهِ.

chapter: Authority often leads to partiality
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 160. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Whoever obtains authority (usually) adopts partiality.
arabicText: ١٦٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ مَلَكَ اسْتَأْثَرَ.

chapter: Self-reliance leads to ruin, consultation fosters wisdom
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 161. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who acts solely according to his own opinion gets ruined, and he who consults other people shares in their understanding.
arabicText: ١٦١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنِ اسْتَبَدَّ بِرَأْيِهِ هَلَكَ، وَمَنْ شَاوَرَ الرِّجَالَ شَارَكَهَا فِي عُقُولِهَا.

chapter: Destitution as the ultimate death
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 163. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Destitution is the greatest death.
arabicText: ١٦٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الْفَقْرُ الْمَوْتُ الْأَكْبَرُ.

chapter: Fulfilling rights of the ungrateful as idolatry
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 164. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who fulfils the right of a man who does not fulfil his right, (is as though he) worships him.
arabicText: ١٦٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ قَضَى حَقَّ مَنْ لَا يَقْضِي حَقَّهُ فَقَدْ عَبَدَهُ.

chapter: Blaming rightful claimants versus unjust takers
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 166. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: No person is to be blamed for delay in (securing) his own right but blame lies on him who takes what he is not entitled to.
arabicText: ١٦٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَا يُعَابُ الْمَرْءُ بِتَأْخِيرِ حَقِّهِ، إِنَّمَا يُعَابُ مَنْ أَخَذَ مَا لَيْسَ لَهُ.

chapter: Vanity hinders progress
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 167. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Vanity prevents progress. [1]
arabicText: ١٦٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الْإِعْجَابُ يَمْنَعُ الِازْدِيَادَ.

chapter: Divine guidance illuminates the perceptive
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 169. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: For the man who has eyes the dawn has already appeared.
arabicText: ١٦٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): قَدْ أَضَاءَ الصُّبْحُ لِذِي عَيْنَيْنِ.

chapter: Avoiding sin is easier than seeking forgiveness
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 170. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Abstention from sin is easier than seeking forgiveness afterwards. [1]
arabicText: ١٧٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): تَرْكُ الذَّنْبِ أَهْوَنُ مِنْ طَلَبِ التَّوْبَةِ.

chapter: People oppose the unknown
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 172. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: People are enemies of what they do not know. [1]
arabicText: ١٧٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): النَّاسُ أَعْدَاءُ مَا جَهِلُوا.

chapter: Multiple opinions reveal pitfalls
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 173. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who has several opinions understands the pitfalls.
arabicText: ١٧٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنِ اسْتَقْبَلَ وُجُوهَ الْآرَاءِ عَرَفَ مَوَاقِعَ الْخَطَاَ.

chapter: Divine empowerment through righteous anger
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 174. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who sharpens the teeth of anger for the sake of Allāh acquires the strength to kill the stalwarts of wrong. [1]
arabicText: ١٧٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَن أَحَدَّ سِنَانَ الْغَضَبِ لله قَوِيَ عَلَى قَتْلِ أَشِدَّاءِ الْبَاطِلِ.

chapter: Generosity as the foundation of leadership
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 176. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The means to secure high authority is breadth of chest (i.e., generosity).
arabicText: ١٧٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): آلَةُ الرِّيَاسَةِ سَعَةُ الصَّدْرِ

chapter: Rewarding the good to rebuke evil
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 177. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Rebuke the evil-doer by rewarding the good-doer. [1]
arabicText: ١٧٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): ازْجُرِ الْمُسِيءَ بِثوَابِ الْـمُحْسِنِ.

chapter: Stubbornness undermines counsel
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 179. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Stubbornness destroys (good) advice.
arabicText: ١٧٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): اللَّجَاجَةُ تَسُلُّ الرَّأْيَ.

chapter: Greed as perpetual enslavement
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 180. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him said: Greed is a lasting slavery.
arabicText: ١٨٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الطَّمَعُ رِقٌّ مُؤَبَّدٌ.

chapter: Silence in wisdom versus speech in folly
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 182. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: There is no advantage ill keeping quiet about an issue of wisdom, just as there is no good in speaking out an unintelligent thing.
arabicText: ١٨٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَا خَيْرَ فِي الصَّمْتِ عَنِ الْحُكْمِ، كَمَا أَنَّهُ لَا خَيْرَ فِي الْقوْلِ بِالْجَهْلِ.

chapter: Two calls signify one leads to misguidance
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 183. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: If there are two different calls then one (of them) must be towards misguidance.
arabicText: ١٨٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَا اخْتَلَفَتْ دَعْوَتَانِ إِلَّا كَانَتْ إِحْدَاهُمَا ضَلاَلَةً.

chapter: Unwavering certainty in recognizing truth
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 184. Amir al-mu'minin, peace be upon him, said: I have never entertained doubt about right since I was shown it.
arabicText: ١٨٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَا شَكَكْتُ فِي الْحَقِّ مُذْ أُرِيتُهُ.

chapter: Oppression leads to inevitable regret
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 186. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who takes the lead in oppression has to bite his hand (in repentance) tomorrow.
arabicText: ١٨٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لِلظَّالِمِ الْبَادِي غَداً بِكَفِّهِ عَضَّةٌ.

chapter: Imminent departure from this world
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 187. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The departure (from this world) is imminent.
arabicText: ١٨٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الرَّحِيلُ وَشِيكٌ.

chapter: Patience as relief versus impatience as destruction
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 189. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: If patience does not give relief to a man impatience kills him.
arabicText: ١٨٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ لَمْ يُنْجِهِ الصَّبْرُ أَهْلَكَهُ الْجَزَعُ.

chapter: Human mortality and life's fleeting nature
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 191. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: In this world man is the target towards which the arrows of death fly, and is like that wealth whose destruction is quickened by hard ships. (In this world) with every drink there is suffocation and with every morsel there is choking. Here no one gets anything unless he loses something else, and not a day of his age advances till a day passes out from his life. Thus, we are helpers of death and our lives are the targets of mortality. How then can we expect everlasting life since the night and day do not raise anything high without quickly arranging for the destruction of whatever they have built and for the splitting asunder of whatever they have joined together.
arabicText: ١٩١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِنَّمَا الْمَرْءُ فِى الدُّنْيَا غَرَضٌ تَنْتَضِلُ فِيهِ الْمَنَايَا وَنَهْبٌ تُبَادِرُهُ الْمَصَائِبُ وَمَعَ كُلِّ جُرْعَةٍ شَرَقٌ وَفِى كُلِّ أَكْلَةٍ غَصَصٌ وَلَا يَنَالُ الْعَبْدُ نِعْمَةً إِلَّا بِفِرَاقِ أُخْرَى وَلَا يَسْتَقْبِلُ يَوْماً مِنْ عُمُرِهِ إِلَّا بِفِرَاقِ آخَرَ مِنْ أَجَلِهِ فَنَحْنُ أَعْوَانُ الْمَنُونِ وَأَنْفُسُنَا نَصْبُ الْحُتُوفِ فَمِنْ أَيْنَ نَرْجُو الْبَقَاءَ وَهَذَا اللَّيْلُ وَالنَّهَارُ لَمْ يَرْفَعَا مِنْ شَيْ‏ءٍ شَرَفاً إِلَّا أَسْرَعَا الْكَرَّةَ فِى هَدْمِ مَا بَنَيَا وَ تَفْرِيقِ مَا جَمَعَا.

chapter: Wealth as stewardship beyond basic needs
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 192. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: O son of Adam, whatever you earn beyond your basic needs you are only a treasurer of it for others.
arabicText: ١٩٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): يَا ابْنَ آدَمَ مَا كَسَبْتَ فَوْقَ قُوتِكَ، فَأَنْتَ فِيهِ خَازِنٌ لِغَيْرِكَ.

chapter: Hearts act best when passionate and willing
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 193. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Hearts are imbued with passion and the power of advancing and retreating. Therefore, approach them for action at the time of their passionateness and when they are in a mood for advancing, because if hearts are forced (to do a thing) they will be blinded.
arabicText: ١٩٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِنَّ لِلْقُلُوبِ شَهْوَةً وَإِقْبَالًا وَإِدْبَاراً، فَأْتُوهَا مِنْ قِبَلِ شَهْوَتِهَا وَإِقْبَالِهَا، فَإِنَّ الْقَلْبَ إِذَا أُكْرِهَ عَمِيَ.

chapter: Misers' niggardly disputes over worthless possessions
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 195. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, passed beside a dump of rubbish full of filth and remarked: This is what the misers used to be niggardly about.
arabicText: ١٩٥. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام) وَقَدْ مَرَّ بِقَذَرٍ عَلَى مَزْبَلَةٍ: هَذَا مَا بَخِلَ بِهِ الْبَاخِلُونَ.

chapter: Misers' niggardly disputes over worthless possessions
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: In another tradition it is related that he said: This is what you used to dispute with each other about until yesterday!
arabicText: وَرُوِيَ فِي خَبَرٍ آخَرَ أَنَّهُ قَالَ: هَذَا مَا كُنْتُمْ تَتَنَافَسُونَ فِيهِ بِالْأَمْسِ!

chapter: Hearts tire like bodies; seek refreshing wisdom
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 197. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The hearts become tired as the bodies become tired. You should therefore search for beautiful sayings for them (to enjoy by way of refreshment).
arabicText: ١٩٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِنَّ هذِهِ الْقُلُوبَ تَمَلُّ كَمَا تَمَلُّ الْأَبْدَانُ، فَابْتَغُوا لَهَا طَرَائِفَ الْحِكْمَةِ.

chapter: Khārijites' misinterpretation of divine verdict
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 198. When Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, heard the slogan of the Khārijites: There is no verdict save of Allāh, he said: This sentence is true but it is interpreted wrongly.
arabicText: ١٩٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام) لَمَّا سَمِعَ قَوْلَ الْخَوَارِجِ ـ لَا حُكْمَ إِلَّا لِلهِ ـ : كَلِمَةُ حَقٍّ يُرَادُ بِهَا بَاطِلٌ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn rebukes the crowd for appearing only in disgraceful situations
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 200. An offender was brought before Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, and there was a crowd of people with the man, so Amīr al-mu’minīn remarked: Woe to the faces who are seen only on foul occasions.
arabicText: ٢٠٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام) وقد أُتي بِجَانٍ وَمَعَهُ غَوْغَاءُ: فَقَالَ : لَا مَرْحَباً بِوُجُوهٍ لَا تُرَى إِلَّا عِنْدَ كُلِّ سَوْأَةٍ .

chapter: Talḥah and Zubayr's conditional allegiance rejected by ʿAlī
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 202. When Ṭalḥah and az-Zubayr said to him: We are prepared to swear allegiance to you on condition that we have a share with you in this matter (of caliphate), Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: No, but you will have a share in strengthening (the caliphate) and in affording assistance and you will both be helping me at the time of need and hardship.
arabicText: ٢٠٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام) وَقَدْ قَالَ لَهُ طَلْحَةُ وَالزُّبَيْرُ: نُبَايِعُكَ عَلَى أَنَّا شُرَكَاؤُكَ فِي هَذَا الْأَمْرِ: لَا، وَلكِنَّكُمَا شَرِيكَانِ فِي الْقُّوَّةَ وَالِاسْتِعَانَةِ، وَعَوْنَانِ عَلَى الْعَجْزِ وَالْأَوَدِ.

chapter: Knowledge expands unlike physical containers
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 205. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Every container gets narrower according to what is placed in it except the container of knowledge which expands instead.
arabicText: ٢٠٥. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): كُلُّ وِعَاءٍ يَضِيقُ بِمَا جُعِلَ فِيهِ إِلَّا وِعَاءَ الْعِلْمِ، فَإِنَّهُ يَتَّسِعُ بِهِ.

chapter: Forbearance earns allies against ignorance
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 206. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The first reward the exerciser of forbearance gets is that people become his helpers against the ignorant.
arabicText: ٢٠٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): أَوَّلُ عِوَضِ الْحَلِيمِ مِنْ حِلْمِهِ أَنَّ النَّاسَ أَنْصَارُهُ عَلَى الْجَاهِلِ.

chapter: Self-reflection benefits, neglect harms; fear ensures safety, observation yields wisdom
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 208. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Whoever takes account of his self is benefited, and whoever remains neglectful of it suffers. Whoever fears remains safe; whoever takes instruction (from things around) perceives; and whoever perceives gains understanding, and whoever gains understanding secures knowledge.
arabicText: ٢٠٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ حَاسَبَ نَفْسَهُ رَبِحَ، وَمَنْ غَفَلَ عَنْهَا خَسِرَ، وَمَنْ خَافَ أَمِنَ، وَمَنِ اعْتَبَرَ أَبْصَرَ وَمَنْ أَبْصَرَ فَهِمَ وَمَنْ فَهِمَ عَلِمَ.

chapter: Fear Allah with preparation and urgency
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 210. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Fear Allāh like the one who prepares himself after extracting himself (from worldly affairs) and after getting ready in this way makes effort; then he acts quickly during the period of this life, hastens in view of the dangers (of falling into error) and has his eye on proceeding towards the goal, on the end of his journey and on the place of his (eventual) return.
arabicText: ٢١٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): اتَّقُوا اللَّهَ تَقِيَّةَ مَنْ شَمَّرَ تَجْرِيداً وَجَدَّ تَشْمِيراً وَكَمَّشَ فِى مَهَلٍ وَبَادَرَ عَنْ وَجَلٍ وَنَظَرَ فِى كَرَّةِ الْمَوْئِلِ وَعَاقِبَةِ الْمَصْدَرِ وَمَغَبَّةِ الْمَرْجِعِ.

chapter: Virtues and vices in leadership and conduct
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 211. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Generosity is the protector of honour; forbearance is the bridle of the fool; forgiveness is the levy of success; disregard is the punishment of him who betrays; and consultation is the chief way of guidance. He who is content with his own opinion faces danger. Endurance braves calamities while impatience is a helper of the hardships of the world. The best contentment is to give up desires. Many a slavish mind is subservient to overpowering longings. Capability helps preservation of experience. Love means well-utilized relationship. Do not trust one who is grieved.
arabicText: ٢١١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الْجُودُ حَارِسُ الْأَعْرَاضِ وَالْحِلْمُ فِدَامُ السَّفِيهِ وَالْعَفْوُ زَكَاةُ الظَّفَرِ وَالسُّلُوُّ عِوَضُكَ مِمَّنْ غَدَرَ وَالِاسْتِشَارَةُ عَيْنُ الْهِدَايَةِ وَقَدْ خَاطَرَ مَنِ اسْتَغْنَى بِرَأْيِهِ وَالصَّبْرُ يُنَاضِلُ الْحِدْثَانَ وَالْجَزَعُ مِنْ أَعْوَانِ الزَّمَانِ وَأَشْرَفُ الْغِنَى تَرْكُ الْمُنَى وَكَمْ مِنْ عَقْلٍ أَسِيرٍ تَحْتَ هَوَى أَمِيرٍ وَمِنَ التَّوْفِيقِ حِفْظُ التَّجْرِبَةِ وَالْمَوَدَّةُ قَرَابَةٌ مُسْتَفَادَةٌ وَلَا تَأْمَنَنَّ مَلُولًا.

chapter: Ignoring pain for lasting happiness
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 213. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Ignore pain otherwise you will never be happy. [Or according to another reading): Ignore pain and grief; you will ever be happy.] [1]
arabicText: ٢١٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): أَغْضِ عَلَى الْقَذَى وَالْأَلَمِ تَرْضَ أَبَداً.

chapter: Soft-trunked trees bear thick branches
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 214. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The tree whose trunk is soft has thick branches. [1]
arabicText: ٢١٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ لَانَ عُودُهُ كَثُفَتْ أَغْصَانُهُ.

chapter: Generosity leads to honor or corruption
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 216. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who gives generously achieves position. (Or according to another interpretation): He who achieves position begins to make wrong use of it.
arabicText: ٢١٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ نَالَ اسْتَطَالَ.

chapter: Revealing character through changing circumstances
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 217. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Through change of circumstances the mettle of men is known.
arabicText: ٢١٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): فِي تَقَلُّبِ الْأَحْوَالِ عِلْمُ جَوَاهِرِ الرِّجَالِ.

chapter: Intellectual deficiency caused by greed
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 219. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Most of the deficiency of intelligence occurs due to the flash of greed. [1]
arabicText: ٢١٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): أَكْثَرُ مَصَارِعِ الْعُقُولِ تَحْتَ بُرُوقِ الْمَطَامِعِ.

chapter: Justice requires certainty, not probability
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 220. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: There is no justice in passing a verdict by relying on probability.
arabicText: ٢٢٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَيْسَ مِنَ الْعَدْلِ الْقَضَاءُ عَلَى الثِّقَةِ بِالظَّنِّ.

chapter: Noble restraint in overlooking known faults
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 222. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The highest act of a noble person is to ignore what he knows.
arabicText: ٢٢٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مِنْ أَشْرَفِ أَفْعَالِ الْكَرِيمِ غَفْلَتُهُ عَمَّا يَعْلَمُ.

chapter: Modesty conceals human flaws
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 223. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Whomever modesty clothes with its dress people cannot see his defects. [1]
arabicText: ٢٢٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ كَسَاهُ الْحَيَاءُ ثَوْبَهُ لَمْ يَرَ النَّاسُ عَيْبَهُ.

chapter: Jealousy overlooks bodily health
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 225. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: It is strange that the jealous do not feel jealous about bodily health. [1]
arabicText: ٢٢٥. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الْعَجَبُ لِغَفْلَةِ الْحُسَّادِ عَنْ سَلاَمَةِ الْأَجْسَادِ.

chapter: Greed shackles with disgrace
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 226. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The greedy is in the shackles of disgrace.
arabicText: ٢٢٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الطَّامِعُ فِي وِثَاقِ الذُّلِّ.

chapter: Displeasure with divine decree and worldly attachment
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 228. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who is sorrowful for this world is in fact displeased with the dispensation of Allāh. He who complains of a calamity that befalls him complains of his Lord (Allāh). He who approaches a rich man and bends before him on account of his riches then two-third of his religion is gone. If a man reads the Qur’ān and on dying goes to Hell then it means that he was among those who treated Divine verses with mockery. If a man’s heart gets attached to the world, then it catches three things, namely worry that never leaves him, greed that does not abandon him and desire which he never fulfils.
arabicText: ٢٢٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ أَصْبَحَ عَلَى الدُّنْيَا حَزِيناً فَقَدْ أَصْبَحَ لِقَضَاءِ اللهِ سَاخِطاً، وَمَنْ أَصْبَحَ يَشَكُو مُصِيبَةً نَزَلَتْ بِهِ فَقَدْ أَصْبَحَ يَشْكُو رَبَّهُ، وَمَنْ أَتى غَنِيَّاً فَتَوَاضَعَ لِغِنَاهُ ذَهَبَ ثُلُثَا دِينِهِ، وَمَنْ قَرَأَ الْقُرْآنَ فَمَاتَ فَدَخَلَ النَّارَ فَهُوَ مِمَّنْ كَانَ يَتَّخِذُ آيَاتِ اللهِ هُزُواً، وَمَنْ لَهِجَ قَلْبُهُ بِحُبِّ الدُّنْيَا الْتَاطَ قَلْبُهُ مِنْهَا بِثَلاَثٍ: هَمٍّ لَا يُغِبُّهُ، وَحِرْصٍ لَا يَتْرُكُه، وَأَمَلٍ لَا يُدْرِكُهُ.

chapter: The virtues of contentment and moral character
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 229. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Contentment is as good as estate, and goodness of moral character is as good as a blessing. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, was asked about Allāh’s saying: We will certainly make him live a life good and pure. (Qur’ān, 16:97) when he said: that means contentment. [1]
arabicText: ٢٢٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): كَفَى بِالْقَنَاعَةِ مُلْكاً، وَبِحُسْنِ الْخُلُقِ نَعِيماً. وَسُئِلَ (عليه السلام) عَنْ قَوْلِهِ تَعَالَى ﴿فَلَنُحْيِيَنَّهُ حَيَاةً طَيِّبَةً﴾ فَقَالَ: هِيَ الْقَنَاعَةُ.

chapter: Divine Command for Justice and Benevolence
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 231. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said about Allāh’s saying: Verily, Allāh enjoins justice (‘adl) and benevolence (iḥsān),(Qur’ān,16:90). Here ‘adl means equidistribution and iḥsān means favour.
arabicText: ٢٣١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام) فِي قَوْلِهِ تَعَالَى ﴿إِنَّ اللهَ يَأْمُرُ بِالْعَدْلِ وَالْإِحْسَانِ﴾: الْعَدْلُ الْإِنْصَافُ، وَالْإِحْسَانُ التَّفَضُّلُ.

chapter: Divine reward for modest charity
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 232. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who gives with his short hand is given by a long hand.
arabicText: ٢٣٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ يُعْطِ بِالْيَدِ الْقَصِيرَةِ يُعْطَ بِالْيَدِ الطَّوِيلَةِ.

chapter: Divine reward for modest charity
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: as-Sayyid ar-Raḍī says: The meaning of this saying is that even though what a man spends in charity from his possessions may be small, yet Allāh, the Sublime, gives good reward for it. And the two hands referred to, here means two favours. Thus, Amīr al-mu’minīn has differentiated between the favour of man and the favour of the Lord (Allāh) — exalted be the mention of His name — since he has described the first as small and the other as big. This is because the favours of Allāh are ever multiplied manifold to the favours of man since Allāh’s favours are basic in the sense that every other favour springs from it and turns to it.
arabicText: قال السيد الرضى: ومعنى ذلك أن ما ينفقه المرء من ماله فى سبيل الخير و البر و إن كان يسيرا فإن الله تعالى يجعل الجزاء عليه عظيما كثيرا و اليدان هاهنا عبارة عن النعمتين ففرق (عليه السلام) بين نعمة العبد و نعمة الرب تعالى ذكره بالقصيرة و الطويلة فجعل تلك قصيرة و هذه طويلة لأن نعم الله أبدا تضعف على نعم المخلوق أضعافا كثيرة إذ كانت نعم الله أصل النعم كلها فكل نعمة إليها ترجع و منها تنزع .

chapter: Gender-specific virtues in traditional Islamic ethics
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 234. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The best traits of women are those which are the worst traits of men, namely: vanity, cowardice and miserliness. Thus, since the woman is vain, she will not allow anyone access to herself; since she is miserly, she will preserve her own property and the property of her husband; and since she is weak-hearted, she will be frightened with everything that befalls her.
arabicText: ٢٣٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): خِيَارُ خِصَالِ النِّسَاءِ شِرَارُ خِصَالِ الرِّجَالِ: الزَّهْوُ وَالْجُبْنُ وَالْبُخْلُ، فَإذَا كَانَتِ الْمَرْأَةُ مَزْهُوَّةً لَمْ تُمَكِّنْ مِنْ نَفْسِهَا، وَإِذَا كَانَتْ بِخِيلَةً حَفِظَتْ مَالَهَا وَمَالَ بَعْلِهَا، وَإِذَا كَانَتْ جَبَانَةً فَرِقَتْ مِنْ كُلِّ شِيْءٍ يَعْرِضُ لَهَا.

chapter: Wisdom and ignorance in proper placement
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 235. It was said to Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him: Describe the wise to us; and he said: The wise is one who places things in their proper positions. Then, he was asked: Describe the ignorant to us; and he said: I have already done so.
arabicText: ٢٣٥. وَقِيلَ لَهُ (عليه السلام): صِفْ لَنَا الْعَاقِلَ. فَقَالَ (عليه السلام): هُوَ الِّذِي يَضَعُ الشَّيْءَ مَوَاضِعَهُ. فَقِيلَ: فَصِفْ لَنَا الْجَاهِلَ. فَقَالَ: قَدْ فَعَلْتُ.

chapter: Wisdom and ignorance in proper placement
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: as-Sayyid ar-Raḍī says: The meaning is that the ignorant is one who does not place things in their proper positions. In this way, Amīr al-mu’minīn’s abstention from describing was a way of describing him because his attributes are just the opposite of the wise.
arabicText: قال السيد الرضى: يعنى أن الجاهل هو الذى لا يضع الشي‏ء مواضعه فكأن ترك صفته صفة له إذ كان بخلاف وصف العاقل.

chapter: Motives for worship: desire, fear, and gratitude
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 237. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: A group of people worshipped Allāh out of desire for reward surely, this is the worship of traders. Another group worshipped Allāh out of fear, this is the worship of slaves. Still another group worshipped Allāh out of gratefulness, this is the worship of free men.
arabicText: ٢٣٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِنَّ قَوْماً عَبَدُوا اللهَ رَغْبَةً فَتِلْكَ عِبَادَةُ التُّجَّارِ، وَإِنَّ قَوْماً عَبَدُوا اللهَ رَهْبَةً فَتِلْكَ عِبَادَةُ الْعَبِيدِ، وَإِنَّ قَوْماً عَبَدُوا اللهَ شُكْراً فَتِلْكَ عِبَادَةُ الْأَحْرَارِ.

chapter: Sluggards lose rights and backbiters lose friends
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 239. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who is a sluggard loses his rights and he who believes in the backbiter loses his friend.
arabicText: ٢٣٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ أَطَاعَ التَّوَانِيَ ضَيَّعَ الْحُقُوقَ، وَمَنْ أَطَاعَ الْوَاشِيَ ضَيَّعَ الصَّدِيقَ.

chapter: Ill-gotten gains lead to ruin
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 240. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: One ill-gotten piece of stone in a house is a guarantee for its ruin.
arabicText: ٢٤٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الْحَجَرُ الْغَصِيبُ فِي الدَّارِ رَهْنٌ عَلَى خَرَابِهَا.

chapter: Ill-gotten gains lead to ruin
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: as-Sayyid ar-Raḍī says: In one tradition this saying is attributed to the Prophet. It is no wonder that the two sayings should resemble each other because they are driven from the same source and dispersed through the same means.
arabicText: قال السيد الرضى: و يروى هذا الكلام عن النبى (ص) و لا عجب أن يشتبه الكلامان لأن مستقاهما من قليب و مفرغهما من ذنوب .

chapter: Fear Allah with even minimal devotion
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 242. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Fear Allāh to some degree (even) though it be little; and set a curtain between you and Allāh (even) though it be thin.
arabicText: ٢٤٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): اتَّقِ اللهَ بَعْضَ التُّقَى وَإِنْ قَلَّ، وَاجْعَلْ بَيْنَكَ وَبَيْنَ اللهِ سِتْراً وَإِنْ رَقَّ.

chapter: Numerous replies obscure correct points
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 243. Amīr al-mu’mnīn, peace be upon him, said: When replies are numerous the correct point remains obscure. [1]
arabicText: ٢٤٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِذَا ازْدَحَمَ الْجَوَابُ خَفِيَ الصَّوَابُ.

chapter: Capability diminishes desire
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 245. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: When capability increases, desire decreases.
arabicText: ٢٤٥. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِذَا كَثُرَتِ الْمَقْدِرَةُ قَلَّتِ الشَّهْوَةُ.

chapter: Vigilance in preserving blessings
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 246. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Keep on guard against the slipping away of blessings because not everything that runs away comes back.
arabicText: ٢٤٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): احْذَرُوا نِفَارَ النِّعَمِ فَمَا كُلُّ شَارِدٍ بِمَرْدُودٍ.

chapter: Generosity surpasses kinship in prompting virtue
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 247. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Generosity is more prompting to good than regard for kinship.
arabicText: ٢٤٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الْكَرَمُ أَعْطَفُ مِنَ الرَّحِمِ.

chapter: Virtue in overcoming reluctance
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 249. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The best act is that which you have to force yourself to do.
arabicText: ٢٤٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): أَفْضَلُ الْأَعْمَالِ مَا أَكْرَهْتَ نَفْسَكَ عَلَيْهِ.

chapter: Understanding Allah through human frailty
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 250. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: I came to know Allāh, the Glorified, through the breaking of determinations, change of intentions and losing of courage. [1]
arabicText: ٢٥٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): عَرَفْتُ اللهَ سُبْحَانَهُ بِفَسْخِ الْعَزَائِمِ وَحَلِّ الْعُقُودِ.

chapter: Divine commandments and their purposes in Islam
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 252. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Allāh has laid down īmān (belief) for purification from polytheism; ṣalāt (prayer) for purification from vanity; zakāt (levy) as a means of livelihood; ṣiyām (fasting) as a trial of the people; ḥajj (pilgrimage to the House of Allāh in Mecca) as a support for religion; jihād (fighting in the way of Allāh) for the honour of Islam; persuasion for good (al-amr bi’l-ma‘rūf ) for the good of the common people; dissuasion from evil (an-nahy ‘ani’l-munkar) for the control of the mischievous; regard for kinship for increase of number; revenge for stoppage of bloodshed; the award of penalties for the realization of importance of the prohibitions; the abstinence from drinking wine for protection of the wit; the avoidance of theft for inculcating chastity; abstinence from adultery for safeguarding descent; abstinence from sodomy for increase of progeny; tendering evidence for furnishing proof against contentions; abstinence from the lie for increasing esteem for truth; maintenance of peace (salām) for protection from danger; imāmah or Imāmate (Divine Leadership) for the orderliness of the community and obedience (to Imāms) as a mark of respect to the Imāmate. [1]
arabicText: ٢٥١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): فَرَضَ اللَّهُ الْإِيمَانَ تَطْهِيراً مِنَ الشِّرْكِ وَالصَّلَاةَ تَنْزِيهاً عَنِ الْكِبْرِ وَالزَّكَاةَ تَسْبِيباً لِلرِّزْقِ وَالصِّيَامَ ابْتِلَاءً لِإِخْلَاصِ الْخَلْقِ وَالْحَجَّ تَقْرِبَةً لِلدِّينِ وَالْجِهَادَ عِزّاً لِلْإِسْلَامِ وَالْأَمْرَ بِالْمَعْرُوفِ مَصْلَحَةً لِلْعَوَامِّ وَالنَّهْيَ عَنِ الْمُنْكَرِ رَدْعاً لِلسُّفَهَاءِ وَصِلَةَ الرَّحِمِ مَنْمَاةً لِلْعَدَدِ وَالْقِصَاصَ حَقْناً لِلدِّمَاءِ وَإِقَامَةَ الْحُدُودِ إِعْظَاماً لِلْمَحَارِمِ وَتَرْكَ شُرْبِ الْخَمْرِ تَحْصِيناً لِلْعَقْلِ وَمُجَانَبَةَ السَّرِقَةِ إِيجَاباً لِلْعِفَّةِ وَتَرْكَ الزِّنَى تَحْصِيناً لِلنَّسَبِ وَتَرْكَ اللِّوَاطِ تَكْثِيراً لِلنَّسْلِ وَالشَّهَادَاتِ اسْتِظْهَاراً عَلَى الْمُجَاحَدَاتِ وَتَرْكَ الْكَذِبِ تَشْرِيفاً لِلصِّدْقِ وَالسَّلَامَ أَمَاناً مِنَ الْمَخَاوِفِ وَالْأَمَانَةَ نِظَاماً لِلْأُمَّةِ وَالطَّاعَةَ تَعْظِيماً لِلْإِمَامَةِ.

chapter: Managing property as one's own representative
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 254. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: O’ son of Adam, be your own representative in the matter of your property and do about it whatever you want to be done with it after your death. [1]
arabicText: ٢٥٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): يَا ابْنَ آدَمَ كُنْ وَصِيَّ نَفْسِكَ فِى مَالِكَ وَاعْمَلْ فِيهِ مَا تُؤْثِرُ أَنْ يُعْمَلَ فِيهِ مِنْ بَعْدِكَ.

chapter: Anger as a form of temporary madness
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 255. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Anger is a kind of madness because the victim to it repents afterwards. If he does not repent his madness is confirmed.
arabicText: ٢٥٥. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): الْحِدَّةُ ضَرْبٌ مِنَ الْجُنُونِ، لاِنَّ صَاحِبَهَا يَنْدَمُ، فَإِنْ لَمْ يَنْدَمْ فَجُنُونُهُ مُسْتَحْكِمٌ.

chapter: Health benefits of minimizing envy
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 256. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Health of body comes from paucity of envy. [1]
arabicText: ٢٥٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): صِحَّةُ الْجَسَدِ مِنْ قِلَّةِ الْحَسَدِ.

chapter: Charitable trade with Allah in destitution
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 258. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: When you fall in destitution, trade with Allāh through charity.
arabicText: ٢٥٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِذَا أَمْلَقْتُمْ فَتَاجِرُوا اللهَ بِالصَّدَقَةِ.

chapter: Divine punishment through worldly indulgence
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 260. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: There is many a man being gradually brought towards punishment by good treatment with him; many a man who remains in deceit because his evils are covered; and many a man who is in illusion because of good talk about him, while there is no greater ordeal by Allāh, the Glorified, than the giving of time.
arabicText: ٢٦٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): كَمْ مِنْ مُسْتَدْرَجٍ بِالْإِحْسَانِ إِلَيْهِ، وَمَغْرُورٍ بِالسَّتْرِ عَلَيْهِ، وَمَفْتُونٍ بِحُسْنِ الْقَوْلِ فِيهِ، وَمَا ابْتَلَى اللهُ سُبْحَانَهُ أَحَداً بِمِثْلِ الْإِمْلَاءِ لَهُ.

chapter: Divine punishment through worldly indulgence
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: as-Sayyid ar-Raḍī says: This saying has appeared earlier as well but here it contains a beautiful and useful addition.
arabicText: قال السيد الرضى: وقد مَضى هذا الكلام فيما تقدم، إلاّ أن فيه هاهنا زيادة مفيدة

chapter: Ali's lament over his people's disobedience
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 261. When the news of the attack of Mu‘āwiyah’s men on al-Anbār reached Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, he himself came out walking till he reached an-Nukhaylah, where people overtook him and said: “O’ Amīr al-mu’minīn, we are enough for them,” then he said:
arabicText: ٢٦١. وقال (عليه السلام) لَمَّا بَلَغَهُ إِغَارَةُ أَصْحَابِ مُعَاوِيَةَ عَلَى الْأَنْبَارِ، فَخَرَجَ بِنَفْسِهِ مَاشِياً حَتَّى أَتَى النُّخَيْلَةَ وَأَدْرَكَهُ النَّاسُ وَقَالُوا: يَا أَمِيرَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ نَحْنُ نَكْفِيكَهُمْ. فَقَالَ (عليه السلام) :

chapter: Ali's lament over his people's disobedience
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: You cannot be enough for me against yourselves, so how can you be enough for me against others? Before me the people used to complain of the oppression of their rulers but now I have to complain of the wrongful actions of my people; as though I am led by them and they are the leaders or that I am the subject and they are the rulers.
arabicText: وَاللهِ مَا تَكْفُونَنِي أَنْفُسَكُمْ، فَكَيْفَ تَكْفُونَنِي غَيْرَكُمْ؟ إِنْ كَانَتِ الرَّعَايَا قَبْلِي لَتَشْكُوا حَيْفَ رُعَاتِهَا، وَإِنَّنِي الْيَوْمَ لَأَشْكُو حَيْفَ رَعِيَّتِي، كَأَنَّنِيَ الْمَقُودُ وَهُمُ الْقَادَةُ، أَوِ ألْمَوْزُوعُ وَهُمُ الْوَزَعَةُ.

chapter: Ali's lament over his people's disobedience
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: The narrator says: When Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, uttered this during his long speech which we have included in the collection of sermons (No. 27), two men from his companions advanced towards him and one of them said : I rule no one except myself and my brother (Qur’ān, 5:25). So, order us with your command, O’ Amīr al-mu’minīn and we will accomplish it. Thereupon, Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: How can you two accomplish what I aim at?
arabicText: فلما قال (عليه السلام) هذا القول، في كلامٍ طويلٍ قد ذكرنا مختارَه في جملةِ الخُطَب، تقدّم إليه رجلان من أصحابه، فقال أحدهما: إنّي لا أملك إلا نفسي وأخي، فَمُرْنا بأمرك يا أميرالمؤمنين نُنْفِد له. فقال (عليه السلام): وأَيْنَ تَقَعَانِ مِمَّا أُريدُ؟

chapter: Discerning right from wrong in leadership
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 262. It is said that al-Ḥārith ibn Ḥawṭ came to Amīr al-mu’minīn, and said: Do you believe I can ever imagine that the people of Jamal were in the wrong?
arabicText: ٢٦٢. وَقِيلَ: إِنَّ الْحَارِثَ بْنَ حَوْطٍ أَتَاهُ (عليه السلام) فَقَالَ: أَ تُرَانِی أَظُنُّ أَصْحَابَ الْجَمَلِ كَانُوا عَلَى ضَلَالَةٍ؟

chapter: Discerning right from wrong in leadership
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: O’ al-Ḥārith! You have seen below yourself but not above yourself, and so you have been confused. Certainly, you have not known right, so that you can recognize the righteous. And you have not known wrong, so that you can recognize the people of wrong!
arabicText: فَقَالَ (عليه السلام) : يَا حَارِثُ، إِنَّكَ نَظَرْتَ تَحْتَكَ وَلَمْ تَنْظُرْ فَوْقَكَ فَحِرْتَ إِنَّكَ لَمْ تَعْرِفِ الْحَقَّ فَتَعْرِفَ مَنْ أَتاهُ، وَلَمْ تَعْرِفِ الْبَاطِلَ فَتَعْرِفَ مَنْ أَتَاهُ.

chapter: Discerning right from wrong in leadership
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Then al-Ḥārith said: In that case, I shall withdraw along with Sa‘d ibn Mālik and ‘Abdullāh ibn ‘Umar;
arabicText: فَقَالَ الْحَارِثُ: فَإِنِّي أَعْتَزِلُ مَعَ سَعِيدِ بْنِ مَالِكٍ وَعَبْدِ اللَّهِ بْنِ عُمَرَ.

chapter: Discerning right from wrong in leadership
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: whereupon Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Verily, Sa‘d and ‘Umar have neither sided with Right nor forsaken Wrong. [1]
arabicText: فَقَالَ (عليه السلام) : إِنَّ سَعِيداً وَعَبْدَ اللهِ بْنَ عُمَرَ لَمْ يَنْصُرَا الْحَقَّ، وَلَمْ يَخْذُلَا الْبَاطِلَ.

chapter: Reciprocal kindness toward the bereaved
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 264. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Do good with the bereaved ones of others so that good is done to your bereaved ones also.
arabicText: ٢٦٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): أَحْسِنُوا فِي عَقِبِ غَيْرِكُمْ تُحْفَظُوا فِي عَقِبِكُمْ.

chapter: Wise words as cure or illness
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 265. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: When the utterance of the wise is to the point it serves as a cure, but if it is wrong it proves like an illness. [1]
arabicText: ٢٦٥. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِنَّ كَلاَمَ الْحُكَمَاءِ إذَا كَانَ صَوَاباً كَانَ دَوَاءً، وَإِذَا كَانَ خَطَأً كَانَ دَاءً.

chapter: Trusting divine provision for future days
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 267. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: O’ son of Adam, do not inflict the worry of the day that has not yet come on the day which has already come, because if that day be in your life Allāh will bestow its livelihood also.
arabicText: ٢٦٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): يَابْنَ آدَمَ، لَا تَحْمِلْ هَمَّ يَوْمِكَ الَّذِي لَمْ يَأْتِكَ عَلَى يَوْمِكَ الَّذِي قَدْ أَتَاكَ، فَإِنَّهُ إِنْ يَكُ مِنْ عُمُرِكَ يَأْتِ اللهُ فِيهِ بِرِزْقِكَ.

chapter: Balanced love and hatred in relationships
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 268. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Have love for your friend up to a limit, for it is possible that he may turn into your enemy some day; and hate your enemy up to a limit for it is possible that he may turn into your friend some day.
arabicText: ٢٦٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): أَحْبِبْ حَبِيبَكَ هَوْناً مَا عَسَى أَنْ يَكُونَ بَغِيضَكَ يَوْماً مَا، وَأَبْغِضْ بَغِيضَكَ هَوْناً مَا عَسَى أَنْ يَكُونَ حَبِيبَكَ يَوْماً مَا.

chapter: Caliph 'Umar's deliberation on Ka'bah ornaments
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 270. It is related that during the days of (Caliph) ‘Umar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb, the question of the excess of the ornaments of the Ka‘bah was mentioned to him and some people suggested: If you prepare with it an army of Muslims that will be a matter of great reward; and what would the Ka‘bah do with the ornaments? ‘Umar thought of doing so but asked Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, when he said:
arabicText: ٢٧٠. وَرُوِيَ أَنَّهُ ذُكِرَ عِنْدَ عُمَرَ بْنِ الْخَطَّابِ فِي أَيَّامِهِ حَلْيُ الْكَعْبَةِ وَكَثْرَتُهُ، فَقَالَ قَوْمٌ: لَوْ أَخَذْتَهُ فَجَهَّزْتَ بِهِ جُيُوشَ الْمُسْلِمِينَ كَانَ أَعْظَمَ لِلْأَجْرِ، وَمَا تَصْنَعُ الْكَعْبَةُ بِالْحَلْيِ؟ فَهَمَّ عُمَرُ بِذَلِكَ، وَسَأَلَ عَنْهُ أَمِيرَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ (عليه السلام).

chapter: Caliph 'Umar's deliberation on Ka'bah ornaments
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: When the Qur’ān was descended on the Prophet, peace be upon him and his descendants, there were four kinds of property. One, the property of Muslim individuals which he distributed among the successors according to fixed shares. Second, the tax (fay’) which he distributed to those for whom it was meant. Third, the One-fifth (khums) levy for which Allāh had fixed the ways of disposal. Fourth, amounts of charity (ṣadaqāt) whose disposal was also fixed by Allāh. The ornaments of Ka‘bah did exist in those days but Allāh left them as they were, but did not leave them by omission, nor were they unknown to Him. Therefore, you retain them where Allāh and His Prophet placed them.
arabicText: فقال (عليه السلام): إِنَّ القُرْآنَ أُنْزِلَ عَلَى النَّبِيِّ (صلى الله عليه وآله) وَالْأَمْوَالُ أَرْبَعَةٌ: أَمْوَالُ الْمُسْلِمِينَ فَقَسَّمَهَا بَيْنَ الْوَرَثَةِ فِي الْفَرَائِضِ، وَالْفَيْءُ فَقَسَّمَهُ عَلَى مُسْتَحِقِّيهِ، وَالْخُمُسُ فَوَضَعَهُ اللهُ حَيْثُ وَضَعَهُ، وَالصَّدَقَاتُ فَجَعَلَهَا اللهُ حَيْثُ جَعَلَهَا. وَكَانَ حَلْيُ الْكَعْبَةِ فِيهَا يَوْمَئِذٍ، فَتَرَكَهُ اللهُ عَلَى حَالِهِ، وَلَمْ يَتْرُكْهُ نِسْيَاناً، وَلَمْ يَخْفَ عَلَيْهِ مَكَاناً، فَأَقِرَّهُ حَيْثُ أَقَرَّهُ اللهُ وَرَسُولُهُ.

chapter: Caliph 'Umar's deliberation on Ka'bah ornaments
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Thereupon, ‘Umar ibn al-Khaṭṭāb said: If you had not been here we would have been humiliated; and he left the ornaments as they were. [1]
arabicText: فقال له عمر: لولاك لافتضحنا. وترك الحَلْي بحاله.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's resolve to enact changes
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 272. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: If my steps acquire firmness out of these slippery places, I will alter several things. [1]
arabicText: ٢٧٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَوْ قَدِ اسْتَوَتْ قَدَمَايَ مِنْ هذِهِ الْمَدَاحِضِ لَغَيَّرْتُ أَشْيَاءَ.

chapter: Divine decree and contentment in livelihood
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 273. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Know with full conviction that Allāh has not fixed for any person more livelihood than what has been ordained in the Book of Destiny, even though his means (of seeking it) may be great, his craving for it intense and his efforts for it acute; nor does the weakness of a person or the paucity of his means stand in the way between what is ordained in the Book of Destiny and himself. He who realizes it and acts upon it is the best of them all in point of comfort and benefit; while he who disregards it and doubts it exceeds all men in disadvantages. Very often a favoured person is being slowly driven (towards punishment) through those favours; and very often an afflicted person is being done good through his affliction. Therefore, O’ listener, increase your gratefulness, lessen your haste and stay within the bounds of your livelihood.
arabicText: ٢٧٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): اعْلَمُوا عِلْماً يَقِيناً أَنَّ اللَّهَ لَمْ يَجْعَلْ لِلْعَبْدِ وَإِنْ عَظُمَتْ حِيلَتُهُ وَاشْتَدَّتْ طَلِبَتُهُ وَ قَوِيَتْ مَكِيدَتُهُ أَكْثَرَ مِمَّا سُمِّيَ لَهُ فِى الذِّكْرِ الْحَكِيمِ وَلَمْ يَحُلْ بَيْنَ الْعَبْدِ فِى ضَعْفِهِ وَقِلَّةِ حِيلَتِهِ وَبَيْنَ أَنْ يَبْلُغَ مَا سُمِّيَ لَهُ فِى الذِّكْرِ الْحَكِيمِ وَالْعَارِفُ لِهَذَا الْعَامِلُ بِهِ أَعْظَمُ النَّاسِ رَاحَةً فِى مَنْفَعَةٍ وَالتَّارِكُ لَهُ الشَّاكُّ فِيهِ أَعْظَمُ النَّاسِ شُغُلًا فِى مَضَرَّةٍ وَرُبَّ مُنْعَمٍ عَلَيْهِ مُسْتَدْرَجٌ بِالنُّعْمَى وَرُبَّ مُبْتَلًى مَصْنُوعٌ لَهُ بِالْبَلْوَى فَزِدْ أَيُّهَا الْمُسْتَنْفِعُ فِى شُكْرِكَ وَقَصِّرْ مِنْ عَجَلَتِكَ وَقِفْ عِنْدَ مُنْتَهَى رِزْقِكَ.

chapter: The destructive consequences of greed and unfulfilled desires
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 275. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Greed takes a person to the watering place but gets him back without letting him drink. It undertakes responsibility but does not fulfil it. Often the drinker gets choked before the quenching of his thirst. The greater the worth of a thing yearned for the greater is the grief for its loss. Desires blind the eyes of understanding. The destined share will reach him who does not approach it.
arabicText: ٢٧٥. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِنَّ الطَّمَعَ مُورِدٌ غَيْرُ مُصْدِرٍ وَضَامِنٌ غَيْرُ وَفِيٍّ وَرُبَّمَا شَرِقَ شَارِبُ الْمَاءِ قَبْلَ رِيِّهِ وَكُلَّمَا عَظُمَ قَدْرُ الشَّيْ‏ءِ الْمُتَنَافَسِ فِيهِ عَظُمَتِ الرَّزِيَّةُ لِفَقْدِهِ وَالْأَمَانِيُّ تُعْمِى أَعْيُنَ الْبَصَائِرِ وَالْحَظُّ يَأْتِى مَنْ لَا يَأْتِيهِ.

chapter: Amīr al-mu’minīn's oath on divine truth
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 277. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: I swear by Him Who let us pass the dark night after which there was a bright day that such and such [1] did not happen.
arabicText: ٢٧٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَا وَالَّذِي أَمْسَيْنَا مِنْهُ فِي غُبْرِ لَيْلَةٍ دَهْمَاءَ تَكْشِرُعَنْ يَوْمٍ أَغَرَّ مَا كَان كَذَا وَكَذَا.

chapter: Consistent small actions outweigh sporadic large efforts
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 278. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: A small action which is continued with regularity is more beneficial than a long one performed with disgust.
arabicText: ٢٧٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): قَلِيلٌ تَدُومُ عَلَيْهِ أَرْجَى مِنْ كَثِيرٍ مَمْلُولٍ مِنْهُ.

chapter: Preparing for life's journey by anticipating distance
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 280. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Whoever keeps in view the distance of the journey remains prepared.
arabicText: ٢٨٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَنْ تَذَكَّرَ بُعْدَ السَّفَرِ اسْتَعَدَّ.

chapter: True observation through wisdom, not eyes
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 281. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Perception by the eyes is not real observation because the eyes sometimes deceive people; but wisdom does not deceive whomsoever it counsels.
arabicText: ٢٨١. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَيْسَتِ الرَّوِيَّةُ كَالْـمُعَايَنَةِ مَعَ الْإِبْصَارِ، فَقَدْ تَكْذِبُ الْعُيُونُ أَهْلَهَا، وَلَا يَغُشُّ الْعَقْلُ مَنِ اسْتَنْصَحَهُ.

chapter: Ignorance rewarded over knowledge
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 283. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The ignorant among you get too much while the learned are just put off.
arabicText: ٢٨٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): جَاهِلُكُمْ مُزْدَادٌ وَعَالِمُكُمْ مُسَوِّفٌ.

chapter: Knowledge dispels excuses
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 284. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Knowledge dispels the excuse of those who advance excuses.
arabicText: ٢٨٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): قَطَعَ الْعِلْمُ عُذْرَ الْمُتَعَلِّلِينَ.

chapter: Hidden evils in apparent goodness
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 286. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: For everything to which people say “how good!” there is an evil hidden in this world.
arabicText: ٢٨٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَا قَالَ النَّاسُ لِشَيْءٍ: طُوبَى لَهُ، إِلَّا وَقَدْ خَبَأَ لَهُ الدَّهْرُ يَوْمَ سَوْءٍ.

chapter: Destiny as a divine mystery beyond human comprehension
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 287. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, was asked about Destiny, when he said: It is a dark path — do not tread upon it, it is a deep ocean — do not dive in it, and it is the secret of Allāh — do not take trouble about (knowing) it.
arabicText: ٢٨٧. وَسُئِلَ عَنِ الْقَدَرِ، فقال: طَرِيقٌ مُظْلِمٌ فَلاَ تَسْلُكُوهُ، وَبَحْرٌعَمِيقٌ فَلاَ تَلِجُوهُ، وَسِرُّ اللهِ فَلاَ تَتَكَلَّفُوهُ.

chapter: Exemplary virtues of a devout brother-in-faith
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 289. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: In the past I had a brother-in-faith [1], and he was prestigious in my view because the world was humble in his eyes, the needs of the stomach did not have sway over him, he did not long for what he did not get; if he got a thing he would not ask for more; most of his time he was silent, if he spoke he silenced the other speakers, he quenched the thirst of questioners, he was weak and feeble but at the time of fighting he was like the lion of the forest or the serpent of the valley.
arabicText: ٢٨٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): كَانَ لِى فِيمَا مَضَى أَخٌ فِى اللَّهِ وَكَانَ يُعْظِمُهُ فِى عَيْنِى صِغَرُ الدُّنْيَا فِى عَيْنِهِ وَكَانَ خَارِجاً مِنْ سُلْطَانِ بَطْنِهِ فَلَا يَشْتَهِى مَا لَا يَجِدُ وَلَا يُكْثِرُ إِذَا وَجَدَ وَكَانَ أَكْثَرَ دَهْرِهِ صَامِتاً فَإِنْ قَالَ بَذَّ الْقَائِلِينَ وَنَقَعَ غَلِيلَ السَّائِلِينَ وَكَانَ ضَعِيفاً مُسْتَضْعَفاً فَإِنْ جَاءَ الْجِدُّ فَهُوَ لَيْثُ غَابٍ وَصِلُّ وَادٍ.

chapter: Exemplary virtues of a devout brother-in-faith
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: He would not put forth an argument unless it was decisive, he would not abuse anyone in an excusable matter unless he had heard the excuse, he would not speak of any trouble except after its disappearance, he would say what he would do, and would not say what he would not do, even if he could be exceeded in speaking, he could not be excelled in silence, he was more eager for keeping quiet than speaking and if two things confronted him he would see which was more akin to the longing of the heart and he would oppose it.
arabicText: لَا يُدْلِى بِحُجَّةٍ حَتَّى يَأْتِيَ قَاضِياً وَكَانَ لَا يَلُومُ أَحَداً عَلَى مَا يَجِدُ الْعُذْرَ فِى مِثْلِهِ حَتَّى يَسْمَعَ اعْتِذَارَهُ وَكَانَ لَا يَشْكُو وَجَعاً إِلَّا عِنْدَ بُرْئِهِ وَكَانَ يَقُولُ مَا يَفْعَلُ وَلَا يَقُولُ مَا لَا يَفْعَلُ وَكَانَ إِذَا غُلِبَ عَلَى الْكَلَامِ لَمْ يُغْلَبْ عَلَى السُّكُوتِ وَكَانَ عَلَى مَا يَسْمَعُ أَحْرَصَ مِنْهُ عَلَى أَنْ يَتَكَلَّمَ وَكَانَ إِذَا بَدَهَهُ أَمْرَانِ يَنْظُرُ أَيُّهُمَا أَقْرَبُ إِلَى الْهَوَى فَيُخَالِفُهُ.

chapter: Exemplary virtues of a devout brother-in-faith
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: These qualities are incumbent upon you. So, you should acquire them and excel each other in them. Even if you cannot acquire them you should know that acquiring a part is better than giving up the whole.
arabicText: فَعَلَيْكُمْ بِهَذِهِ الْخَلَائِقِ فَالْزَمُوهَا وَتَنَافَسُوا فِيهَا فَإِنْ لَمْ تَسْتَطِيعُوهَا فَاعْلَمُوا أَنَّ أَخْذَ الْقَلِيلِ خَيْرٌ مِنْ تَرْكِ الْكَثِيرِ.

chapter: Divine obedience through gratitude for God's favors
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 290. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Even if Allāh had not warned of chastisement on those disobedient to Him, it would be obligatory by way of gratefulness for His favours that He should not be disobeyed.
arabicText: ٢٩٠. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَوْ لَمْ يَتَوَعَّدِ اللهُ عَلَى مَعْصِيَةٍ لَكَانَ يَجِبُ أَنْ لَّا يُعْصَى شُكْراً لِنِعَمِهِ.

chapter: Amir al-mu'minin's lamentation for the Prophet's passing
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 292. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said on the grave of the Messenger of Allāh, peace be upon him and his descendants, at the time of burial:
arabicText: ٢٩٢. وَقَالَ (عليه السلام): عَلَى قَبْرِ رَسُولِ اللَّهِ (صلى الله عليه وآله) سَاعَةَ دَفْنِهِ:

chapter: Amir al-mu'minin's lamentation for the Prophet's passing
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Certainly, endurance is good except about you; fretting is bad except over you; and the affliction about you is great while every other affliction before or after it is small.
arabicText: إِنَّ الصَّبْرَ لَجَمِيلٌ إِلَّا عَنْكَ، وَإِنَّ الْجَزَعَ لَقَبِيحٌ إِلَّا عَلَيْكَ، وَإِنَّ الْمُصَابَ بِكَ لَجَلِيلٌ، وَإِنَّهُ قَبْلَكَ وَبَعْدَكَ لَجَلَلٌ.

chapter: Avoiding association with fools
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 293. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Do not associate with a fool because he will beautify his actions before you and long that you too be like him. [1]
arabicText: ٢٩٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): لَا تَصْحَبِ الْمَائِقَ فَإِنَّهُ يُزَيِّنُ لَكَ فِعْلَهُ، وَيَوَدُّ أَنْ تَكُونَ مِثْلَهُ.

chapter: Three types of friends and enemies
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 295. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Your friends are three and your enemies are (also) three. Your friends are: your friend, your friend’s friend and your enemy’s enemy. And your enemies are: your enemy, your friend’s enemy and your enemy’s friend.
arabicText: ٢٩٥. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): أَصْدِقَاؤُكَ ثَلاَثَةٌ، وَأَعْدَاؤُكَ ثَلاَثَةٌ: فَأَصْدِقَاؤُكَ: صَدِيقُكَ، وَصَدِيقُ صَدِيقِكَ، وَعَدُوُّ عَدُوِّكَ. وَأَعْدَاؤكَ: عَدُوُّكَ، وَعَدُوُّ صَدِيقِكَ، وَصَدِيقُ عَدُوِّكَ.

chapter: Self-harm in pursuit of harming others
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 296. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, saw a man busy against his enemy with what was harmful to himself too, so he said: You are like one who pierces a spear through himself in order to kill the person sitting behind him.
arabicText: ٢٩٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام) لِرَجُلٍ رَآهُ يَسْعَى عَلَى عَدُوٍّ لَهُ بِمَا فِيهِ إِضْرَارٌ بِنَفْسِهِ: إنَّمَا أَنْتَ كَالطَّاعِنِ نَفْسَهُ لِيَقْتُلَ رِدْفَهُ.

chapter: Excessive quarreling leads to sin while deficiency invites oppression
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 298. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: He who goes too far in quarrelling is a sinner, but if one falls short in it, one is oppressed and it is difficult for a quarreller to fear Allāh.
arabicText: ٢٩٨. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَن بَالَغَ فِي الْخُصوُمَةِ أَثِمَ، وَمَنْ قَصَّرَ فِيهَا ظُلِمَ، وَلَا يَسْتَطِيعُ أَنْ يَتَّقِيَ اللهَ مَنْ خَاصَمَ.

chapter: Divine sustenance and accountability parallels
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 300. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, was asked: How Allāh would conduct the accounting of all persons despite their large number.
arabicText: ٣٠٠. وَسُئِلَ (عليه السلام) : كَيْفَ يُحَاسِبُ اللَّهُ الْخَلْقَ عَلَى كَثْرَتِهِمْ؟

chapter: Divine sustenance and accountability parallels
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: He replied: Just as He provides them livelihood despite their large number.
arabicText: فَقَالَ (عليه السلام) : كَمَا يَرْزُقُهُمْ عَلَى كَثْرَتِهِمْ.

chapter: Divine sustenance and accountability parallels
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: Then it was said to him: How will He conduct their accounting without their seeing Him.
arabicText: فَقِيلَ: كَيْفَ يُحَاسِبُهُمْ وَلَا يَرَوْنَهُ؟

chapter: Divine sustenance and accountability parallels
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: He replied: Just as He provides them livelihood although they do not see Him.
arabicText: فَقَالَ (عليه السلام) : كَمَا يَرْزُقُهُمْ وَلَا يَرَوْنَهُ.

chapter: Hardship's inevitability and prayer's necessity
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 302. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The person who is afflicted with hardship is not in greater need of praying than the one who has been spared affliction but is not immune from it.
arabicText: ٣٠٢. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): مَا الْمُبْتَلَى الَّذِي قَدِ اشْتَدَّ بِهِ الْبَلاَءُ، بِأَحْوَجَ إِلَى الدُّعَاءِ مِنَ المُعَافَى الَّذِي لَا يَأمَنُ البَلاَءَ.

chapter: People's love for the world as their mother
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 303. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: People are the progeny of the world and no one can be blamed for loving the mother.
arabicText: ٣٠٣. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): النَّاسُ أَبْنَاءُ الدُّنْيَا، وَلاَ يُلاَمُ الرَّجُلُ عَلَى حُبِّ أُمِّهِ.

chapter: Destitute as the Messenger of Allah
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 304. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The destitute is the Messenger of Allāh. Whoever denies him denies Allāh and whoever gives him gives Allāh.
arabicText: ٣٠٤. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): إِنَّ الْمِسْكِينَ رَسُولُ اللهِ، فَمَنْ مَنَعَهُ فَقَدْ مَنَعَ اللهَ، وَمَنْ أَعْطَاهُ فَقَدْ أَعْطَى الله.

chapter: Life's brevity necessitates vigilance
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 306. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: The fixed limit of life is enough to remain watchful. [1]
arabicText: ٣٠٦. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): كَفَى بِالْأَجَلِ حَارِساً.

chapter: Patience in grief versus material loss
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 307. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: A man can sleep on the death of his child, but cannot sleep at loss of property.
arabicText: ٣٠٧. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): يَنَامُ الرَّجُلُ عَلَى الثُّكْلِ وَلَا يَنَامُ عَلَى الْحَرَبِ.

chapter: Patience in grief versus material loss
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: as-Sayyid ar-Raḍī says: It means that a man keeps patience on the death of his children but does not do so on the loss of property.
arabicText: قال السيد الرضى: ومعنى ذلك: أنه يصبر على قتل الاَولاد، ولا يصبر على سلب الاَموال.

chapter: Believers' insights reflect divine truth
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 309. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Be afraid of the ideas of believers, because Allāh, the Sublime, has put truth on their tongues.
arabicText: ٣٠٩. وَقَالَ (عليه ‏السلام): اتَّقُوا ظُنُونَ الْمُؤْمِنِينَ، فَإِنَّ اللهَ تَعَالَى جَعَلَ الْحَقَّ عَلَى أَلْسِنَتِهِمْ.

chapter: Balancing obligatory and optional acts in fluctuating devotion
author: al-Sharīf al-Raḍī
englishText: 312. Amīr al-mu’minīn, peace be upon him, said: Sometimes the hearts move forward and sometimes they move backward. When they move forward get them to perform the optionals (as well), but when they move backward keep them confined to obligatories only.
